title: What source of music do most radio stations use these days? CD's, records or music streaming apps such as iTunes, Spotify and Pandora? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most stations these days are partially or fully automated, with software designed for the purpose, and using files on a PC or server. These may be lossy or lossless files in a variety of formats. The software loads the next event while the current one is playing so that it can cross-fade tracks. The station may or may not have turntables, CD or cart decks that could be put on air. I suspect many do not; most get music from syndication services as files or discs. Some may also use satellite feeds for part or all of the day. The DJs don’t even have to be there; they can pre-record a week’s worth of patter in a few hours, to be placed appropriately by the software.
For decades, radio stations use sowtwares specially designed for music rotation. It is a server that contains thousands of tracks in digital format, which are categorized for proper programming.
